data.text: We were delighted to welcome the two winning Belgian teams from the #GenerationEuro Students' Award this week. Neither team could attend the award event back in April. During the visit, they received their awards from Peter Praet, Member of the Executive Board. https://t.co/XzOsdBl0Ej

The framework will help make the European financial sector more resilient to cyberattacks. But why is cyber resilience important for the financial sector and what is the ECB’s role? Read our second explainer to find out https://t.co/ujUimreLlN 4/4

A unique feature of the European Framework for Threat Intelligence-based Ethical Red Teaming (TIBER-EU) is that cross-border financial companies can get an EU-wide seal of approval once they have been ethically hacked in one country https://t.co/7VJARj8ONC 3/4

Banks or financial companies can use controlled hacking to test and improve their resilience to cyberattacks. Today we have published EU-wide guidance on this. Here is the press release and the full framework https://t.co/D72ykkJ8ym 2/4
(THREAD) What if your bank gets hacked? Watch our explainer on how the ECB is helping the financial system stay safe by encouraging ethical hacking 1/4 https://t.co/Z9ZdQaYCJ3

The changing distribution of assets across the financial system – in particular, how systemic risk migrates to non-bank financial entities – needs to be monitored. This calls for appropriate macroprudential policies (4/4)

The increased competition for assets between banks and asset managers has resulted in banks being less inclined to hold risky assets. At the same time, higher capital requirements may also explain the increase in safe assets in banks’ portfolios (3/4) https://t.co/b9x8wrU6Qf https://t.co/iWzbk57NkL

While the asset management sector in the EU has grown significantly in the past decade, the size of the banking sector has stagnated. This has led banks and investment funds to increasingly compete for assets (2/4) https://t.co/b9x8wrU6Qf

(THREAD) How do competition & regulation drive risk profiles of banks and investment funds? Here’s a thread summarising our latest Macroprudential Bulletin article on it (1/4) https://t.co/b9x8wrU6Qf https://t.co/CcLGDpKNfF

A robust and properly designed regulatory framework is necessary to effectively implement macroprudential policy in the European Union. Read more in the Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/hDCsECxW2z https://t.co/a9HHfeTP64
Interested in financial stability? The fifth issue of the Macroprudential Bulletin is now available on the ECB’s website and has a completely new design. Read it here https://t.co/hDCsECxW2z

The ECB has set supervisory fees at €474.8 million for 2018. The total amount is more than last year, owing to various factors including costs related to Brexit and biennial stress tests. Read our press release to find out more https://t.co/9aOQSWKQue

Introductory statement Mario Draghi to the press conference https://t.co/xsLIU7Faou
Draghi to Constâncio: You have been fundamental in the decisions we have taken. It is the passion with which you put forward your arguments that you will be remembered for.
Constâncio:  I will leave with a sense of the work almost done. And that monetary policy in the next few years will not be as exciting as when I first came.

Constâncio: The growing importance of the non-bank part of the financial system means the spectrum of interest rates that is important is different. Other instruments may become necessary and a broader targeting of interest rates, in the medium to long term.
Draghi: What is known that recent events [regarding protectionism] have a profound and rapid effect on business and exporters'confidence and that in turn can effect the growth outlook
Draghi: US yield increase was to be expected for two reasons: different position in the business cycle of US economy and recent measures concerning fiscal expansion
Draghi: Words we use are patience, prudence and persistence
Draghi: Convergence remains conditional on an ample degree of monetary accommodation
Draghi: The bottom line is caution tempered by unchanged confidence in the convergence of inflation toward our overall aim
Draghi: Some normalisation was expected, mostly due to temporary factors, for example cold weather, strikes, timing of Easter.
Draghi: All Governing Council members reported on the situation of their own countries. All experienced some moderation in growth or loss of momentum. It is pretty broad across countries and sectors

Draghi: Improving the functioning of Economic and Monetary Union remains a priority. The Governing Council urges specific and decisive steps to complete the banking union and the capital markets union.
Draghi: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook remain broadly balanced, but risks related to global factors, including the threat of increased protectionism, have become more prominent
Draghi: Continued monetary support is provided by the net purchases, the sizeable stock of assets, the ongoing and forthcoming reinvestments, and by forward guidance on rates
Draghi: An ample degree of monetary stimulus remains necessary  for underlying inflation pressures to continue to build up
Draghi: The Governing Council will continue to monitor developments in the exchange rate and other financial conditions with regard to their possible implications for the inflation outlook
Draghi: Underlying inflation remains subdued and has yet to show convincing signs of a sustained upward trend
Draghi: The underlying strength of the euro area economy continues to support our confidence that inflation will converge toward our inflation aim of below but close to 2% over the medium term

Draghi: Following several quarters of higher than expected growth, incoming information since our March meeting points towards some moderation, while remaining consistent with a solid and broad-based expansion of the euro area economy

Draghi: Net asset purchases, at current monthly pace of €30 bn, are intended to run until the end of September 2018, or beyond, if necessary and at any case until Governing Council sees sustained adjustment in path of inflation consistent with inflation aim
Draghi: We continue to expect interest rates to remain at their present levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of our net asset purchases
